list_definition.definition: a usually short, not very thick, piece of wood, metal etc used to fasten or mark something

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: There were four pegs stuck in the ground.

list_definition.definition: a hook on a wall or door for hanging clothes etc on

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Hang your clothes on the pegs in the cupboard.

list_definition.definition: (also clothes-peg) a wooden or plastic clip for holding clothes etc to a rope while drying.

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She pegged the clothes on the washing-line.

list_ex_of_english: The applied forces and moment are varied by adjusting the relative position and orientation between the pegs and the holes.
The exact geometry of the pegs and the holes is important for predicting contact-states at a given insertion depth.
To overcome this problem the authors suggested the application of small motions of the peg around the contact point.
Knees are shown but no depiction of feet; the legs end in a ring below which is a round peg base 8 cm long.
The feet have four toes each, and below the feet extends a 2.5 cm-long peg base.
It is assumed that the peg is infinitely rigid, and thus, deformation appears on the cart side only.
Finally, the prefix serves as a ' peg element ', inserted if there is no other syllable preceding the stem.
The peg is then inserted into a pre-specified hole at reduced speed and released.
